>Is it bad that I haven’t seen it?
No, but watch it at some point. Worst case scenario you've acquainted yourself with an important classic. With regards to Babylon, as soon as you see 1927 appear on the screen 'Singing in the rain' must come to your mind even if it's not necessary to understand every reference. It will elevate the experience though. Babylon is trying join the conversation of Singing in the Rain as well as Sunset Boulevard and films like that

But Manny watching the film is essential for Babylon because his viewing of tSingning in the Rain leads into a vision/hallucination/premonition of the history of cinema itself. It serves as the reckoning moment, when he realizes he was, at some point, an integral part of a thing that has developed a neverending cyclical movement of its own. He witnessed first-hand the end of the first cycle (1890-1927) and got chewed out. But he realizes it's become an essential aspect of contemporary life, which is both beautiful and disturbing, since cinema is both spontaneous and mechanical, etc. If the ending part had gotten cut out, if Manny didn't watch his own story unfold on the big screen, thent his emotional ambivalence is lost and the film is reduced to LE WACKY PEOPLE (not that the film wasn't banking on this aspect to get people hooked though)

>No, I didn't have to try for ambiguity; it was inevitable. And I think in a film like 2001, where each viewer brings his own emotions and perceptions to bear on the subject matter, a certain degree of ambiguity is valuable, because it allows the audience to "fill in" the visual experience themselves. In any case, once you're dealing on a nonverbal level, ambiguity is unavoidable. But it's the ambiguity of all art, of a fine piece of music or a painting -- you don't need written instructions by the composer or painter accompanying such works to "explain" them. "Explaining" them contributes nothing but a superficial "cultural" value which has no value except for critics and teachers who have to earn a living. Reactions to art are always different because they are always deeply personal.

>They are the areas I prefer not to discuss because they are highly subjective and will differ from viewer to viewer. In this sense, the film becomes anything the viewer sees in it. Modern french cinema is dying "and it's a good thing". Here's why.

A new Asterix movie is out today. It's going to flop and I'm happy about it.Why ? Asterix is a beloved franchise, from franco-belge BD, an embodiment of french culture, not the snobby arrogant culture the US seems to have associated to us but a more popular, honest and humouristic culture. It's good, read it (not the recent ones).

Of course they tried to adapt it. The animes are good, even the recent ones, and the movies...
Movie 1: Awful
Movie 2: Good
Movie 3: Atrocious

And movie 4 is out today. For this one, they tried at first to co-product with China, to get more money, spending it on useless guest stars and overpriced CGIs. But China finally said no. Why ? Because the scenario involved China being invaded by the Roman Empire and saved by Asterix (played by the realisator) after a romance with the Chinese Princess.

And they still don't understand why China said no. So they made the movie with their own money and are now whining on TV, saying it will be the "end of French cinema" if we don't see the movie as they can't find investors for big french productions anymore.

Please. Let them die.

The thing about the supposed replicant "retcon" is that it's so subtle that most viewers wouldn't even notice what it's trying to convey. So Scott inserted a dream about a unicorn, which in turn is supposed to mean that Gaff's origami unicorn at the end is hinting to Deckard that Gaff "knows" he's a replicant. Or it could be that the unicorn is a coincidence. Maybe he was just fucking with Deckard, as he had been known to do. Ridley Scott has a certain finesse that most directors lack, he knows it's better to leave things open to interpretation so different people can have different takes on the film. And regardless of how people interpret it, it's better than this bullshit:
>Gaff had been there, and let her live. Four years, he figured. He was wrong. Tyrell had told me Rachael was special. No termination date. I didn't know how long we had together... Who does?

>>180013132
Primordial story tropes, a movie about family that has some traditional values actually extolled properly. An appreciation of nature that is unique; we see these Na'vi, who we want to fuck, or be, or at the very least are captivated by. We see them live in nature and appreciate it, and vicariously we do as well. The exotic flora and fauna of Pandora represent that to us; we are seeing nature all over again, as if for the first time.

And there is some other more mysterious power somehow, somewhere in Avatar that emotionally resonates with a lot of people.

The relationship was ridiculously well done; like it was a more convincing relationship than the thousands of straight ones we see in fiction.

It was just so natural how they had Frank hit three home runs in the span of a meal. He caught the wine pairing, the identified the antique piano, and he fucking pulled the right song out of the pile of books.

I understand people's frustrations not seeing Bill and Joel do their thing from this game, but seeing them meet together for the first time was just as good. Just watching them straight talk each other and bond over their shared paranoia was actually excellent. It massively enhanced the relationship they had in the game even if the canon doesn't line up - you just felt like they were the same characters. You just got all the fucking glue that held together their relationship like Tess and Frank helping them get over their stupid shittiness like "Well, our wives like each other so I guess we have to like each other". Actually fucking making the Linda Ronstadt song Ellie finds in the truck have relevance to their connection - a connection they don't actually make was just poetic as fuck; it just made the letter that much more sincere that they would be better friends if they had more time.

>>180003381
BAD ARGUMENTS FOR WHY BALDWIN SHOULD BE CHARGED
>He should have checked the weapon
Generally speaking, on film sets, this is not the case. All weapons are to be thoroughly checked by the master armorer before and after use. This check includes inspecting the barrel of the weapon to ensure there are no obstructions. In order for the actor to check the ammunition, they would have to perform the full check over again. The reason for this chain of command is to ensure that a firearms expert is the last line of defense, not an actor. Those people should not be trusted with eating utensils. I've worked with them before. It's better this way.
>He was a producer on the film
This is just a bad argument. His duties as a producer had to do with creative decisions concerning the script and also marketing the movie. It wasn't his responsibility to hire the armorer or anything like that

GOOD ARGUMENTS FOR WHY HE SHOULD BE CHARGED
>He fucking lied. Multiple times. One of these times was during an official police interview after he was Mirandized
In his initial interview with police, he emphatically stated that Gutierrez (the armorer) handed him the weapon which killed Hutchins. This by itself is a massive breach in safety protocol. In subsequent interviews, he stated the 1st AD handed him the gun. He also claimed he didn't pull the trigger, and stated that he would never aim a gun at someone and pull the trigger, even if it was cold. This indicated that he is well familiar with gun safety protocols and that he knew what he did was a breach of said protocols. Problem for Baldwin is that the FBI did forensics on the weapon in question and determined that there is no way for the gun to misfire without the trigger being pulled.
>There is no reason to aim a gun at a crew member under any circumstances
In a scene which a gun is to be aimed near the camera, the crew is supposed to be out of the line of fire.

>>180015877
>So if you need a close up of a real bullet, you'll have one of those instead
Actually if you want a close up of the real bullet or of the barrel with the bullet inside you can get reverse blanks (there's a proper name for them I think but I can't remember it), they have the projectile but no gunpowder.
That's actually how Brandon Lee died, instead of buying these reverse blanks the crew decided to homebrew them by removing the projectile from a regular live bullet, taking the gunpowder out and then putting the projectile back in. But because they didn't do a great job one of the projectiles came loose and got stuck inside the barrel, when they switched back to blanks for a different scene the projectile was in the barrel and got propelled by the blank and killed him.

>do addicts experience chemical reactions more intensely than non-addicts?
I can only speak for myself but yes, in a way. I have weird reactions to taking any medication but it varies. Some things will do nothing for me, like Novocaine or Vicoden. But I'm extra sensitive to ibuprofen and it makes me irrationally angry for some reason. And something like benadryl I can't take everyday or I build a tolerance in days and need like 5 on day 5 to have the same effect as 1 on day 1.
I think it's both. There are people out there that know they'd be bad with addiction so they never touch anything in the first place.
I think it happens more when someone is using to self medicate over just having a fun time. The fun time people for the most part can just put it down or go through rehab easily if they want to. Drugs/alcohol does make you feel better or at least OK for a time, so it's hard to not go back to that easy quick solution when yo usober up and have to actually work on what made you get high or drunk in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180021612

It's a question of insight.

The ominous feeling as you describe it comes from the contrast between Sophie's perspective into her father's mental state and the insight that Callum shares with the audience.

The vulnerability of Sophie's childhood is reflected and juxtaposed with Callum's own vulnerability.

Of course the ending is telegraphed. This isn't a thriller or a detective movie. It's an autobiographical reflection on a girl's final days with her father. You are supposed to know that "something terrible happens" to put the interactions into context.

whilst the "question of insight" you describe might have potentially been the intention, that is NOT how it is portrayed in the movie

the movie literally plays out like a horror movie, with suspenseful music, and constant foreshadowing of something terrible happening. the movie is trying to make you feel tense in situations that don't actually have any tension at all. there are multiple points in the movie where they drop hints in conversation that suggest either she is going to get killed, or raped, or that he is going to die in front of her, or kill himself and she finds him, etc.

as I mentioned before, there is literally a jumpscare in the middle of the movie, where they make it look like she's about to be assaulted. what was the point of that? you have a scene where he teaches her to defend herself whilst she kind of ignores it, foreshadowing that she'll be put in that situation later in the movie and fail to defend herself due to her not paying attention, but that never comes to fruition. you have this older girl giving her an all-inclusive armband, which was used before to buy alcohol, foreshadowing that she's going to get into a dangerous situation. but nope

holy fuck, you literally have a whole enormous sequence where he leaves her alone at night, she wanders around which is shot like a fucking horror movie, he literally walks into the ocean and disappears into the shot, she can't get into the hotel room because she doesn't have the key, all of this is just fucking teasing you to be terrified and think that it finally happened, he killed himself and she's gonna find out. but nope, he's just naked asleep on the bed

my point is that the dialogue, music, pacing, and visual language of the movie is constantly suggesting that something horrifying is going to happen, and everything is building towards that at all times, but then supposedly that's not the point of the movie. bullshit

>>180015982
It really didn't resolve. He was talking with some serial killer and trying to figure out why he did it. The killer (I think it was the guy who played the SHIELD agent) wanted to be understood by someone. He was saying looking into someone's eyes as you're killing them is like watching someone terrified standing on the edge of a pit before they fall in. Dutch couldn't really grasp the concept and the killer mocked him, saying he wasn't the guy to understand. Knowing Dutch, this really upset him because he thought of himself as the serial killer guru. So later that night he strangled the cat while looking into its eyes to see what the killer was talking about. The only time it was even hinted at again was later in the show he gets a pet cat, or pets a cat or something. But it's never brought up again, never explored anymore, and that was pretty much it.

>>180016345
I'm sure in real life Stallone is a much better person than Arnie. When Demolition Man was being filmed they used a building in Louisville KY set to be imploded for the film. They let us all come down there and watch it, and Stallone and Snipes were supposed to show up and greet people. I was there with my dad and he took me cause I was so hyped. We waited for a hours and Snipes showed up first. He walked past everyone and wouldn't even look at anyone. I was really bummed but my dad was like "Hey, Sly is still coming" and sure enough, he showed up about 15min after. He spent hours walking around and talking to, taking pics, and signing autographs. He talked to me and my dad for about 10min and even let me do my shitty Cobra impression and laughed his ass off when I did it. One of my favorite memories with my dad. Predator is still in my top 10 films of all time though.

>>179993818
Out of all the movies there are maybe 2-3 that are actual good movies( Original 54, Shine G)
The 60s-70s Showa movies are a mixed bag that get progressively cheaper/campier as time goes on, but even some of the campier movies are a lot of fun to watch and the era closes on a high note with Terror of Mechagodzilla.
The 90s Heisei movies are a lot more serious in tone and are the high water mark for suitmation. There still kinda goofy though and not as loved as the showa era cuz most of the battles are just monsters blasting beams at each other.
2000s Millennium movies are generally considered the worst set of movies sense Toho was forced to take Godzilla out of hiatus prematurely due to the 1998 movie bombing. GMK is the one movie worth watching from this era and is one of the better Godzilla movies made. Some people really like Final wars, but it has too much shitty CGI for my taste.
The 1998 movie is alright and not as bad as people say it is.
The legendary movies are a not bad, but more enjoyable if you've seen the old ones.
Don't watch the animes unless you really want more G content.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179996975
This. It's all about what you want out of a Godzilla film. The series has covered everything from children's flickshows to borderline horror.
If you want something serious the Showa series will be very hit or miss, but if you want campy fun it's near perfect. Likewise if you want campy fun you'll be disappointed by the darker tone and better effects of Heisei, whereas if you want more serious sci-fi and political commentary it's awesome. The millennium era was sort of a combination of the two with over the top sci-fi but still a consistent amount of taking itself seriously, just not too much so.
Even from the get-go Gojira '54 was a very dark, brooding commentary on atomic annihilation with a very slow buildup and a surprisingly noir style about it, then immediately followed up with Godzilla Raids Again which dove head first into just being two dudes in rubber suits wrestling on top of cheaply made miniatures.
I'd say a majority of the Heisei films and most of the Showa films directed by Ishiro Honda absolutely hold up. Millennium is beloved by a lot of fans but I'm pretty meh on it, mostly due to the inclusion of some cheap 2000s CGI. Shin is a masterpiece and the new American films are solid though marred in Hollywood cliches.

Overall if you're going in blind you can't expect it to be too serious nor can you count on Godzilla dancing while the children of Japan sing about him. The whole franchise has been like 40% artistic vision and 60% peak Japanese pulp.

I'd say for sure one of the greatest. And I don't mean it because it has largest fanbase. It's sizeable and still growing (amazing for something this old) but it's not the largest. The music is fantastic and one of the best in cinema history but I think it's (one of) the best because it's so flexible and durable. It's so reliable, so dependable.

>>180003990
One thing I love about Godzilla movies is that they were essentially commercial products meant to cash in on the rise of Western monster movies but were made by artists on an incredibly limited budget. That's why the Ishiro Honda ones are so kino, he was a great director (best bros with Kurosawa and sometimes acted as his second unit director, btw) tasked with making popcorn flicks with nothing but rubber suits, wires, and toy tanks, so he and the crew genuinely put their hearts into it and the end product is well-crafted memorable movies that still managed to fill theater seats and enthrall kids looking for late night monster movie action.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180004986
>>180003990
To add to that point, it's a recurring theme lots of Japanese commercial art. Cowboy Bebop was originally commissioned because the studio just wanted an anime with cool spaceship designs to sell toys and didn't give a shit with the rest, so when they turned in the designs and the studio execs said "yeah the kids will loves these, now do whatever the fuck you want" they pumped out kino. Same story with Evangelion and just wanting to pump out another monster-of-the-week vs robots show.

>>180007360
The 1954 movie was successful enough. the American edit made it a hit overseas, later monster movies proved that the market is good for this kind of movies even as they started disappearing from the West then the last of them - Gorgo premieres in Japan in 1961 which kind of reminded Toho of Godzilla (there's nothing in the movie itself that influenced the later Showa movies), KKvs.G was the biggest hit yet and by 1964 Tanaka had a great idea to turn Godzilla into the star of the franchise and make him a more positive character. All of the elements were necessary.
Or even before that the 1952 re-release of King Kong and Shigeru Kayama's short story "The Jira Monster".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What do you all think of the animated movie trilogy? Its weaknesses are clear, with the extremely disappointing third movie, and the second movie basically being the first movie again, but I think it has a lot of strengths too. It did things with the franchise that they've never done before and short of the actual nuclear reality of the first movie, it's by far the most depressing Godzilla installment. I think it would have been better if it got the anime instead of Singular Point, which was barely Godzilla anyway. 3 full movies was way too much for the plot it had, but 12 episodes would be about right.

I really liked the alien race drama. But by far the best part was in the otherwise shitty third movie when Ghidorah made his entrance. That shit was unironically one of the best space horror scenes I've ever seen. It's too bad it was surrounded by shit. Also too bad it has some of the worst all CG I've ever seen. But I think they were an interesting experiment for the franchrise despite their shortcomings.

>>180018579
>>180017289
>>180018692
L O S T relied on weekly episodes, water coolerism, whatever. LOST, Prison Break, and 24 were some of the first shows I actually paid attention to on a weekly basis when they were actually currently airing.
LOST was also the least interesting from a "oh shit I wanna see what happens next" -- It did, however, generate extremely fun conversations with other people I knew that followed it and the few times they missed the new episode it felt fucking bad because of how much I enjoyed the constant wonderment.

The flashbacks were almost entirely a drag barring Jack/Locke/Sawyer/Faraday/Desmond and I liked Juliet's cause it was about the Others and was post-crash. Kate had some of the worst. Jin/Sun were the absolute worst. Hurley was whatever.
The flash sideways and flash forwards were extremely interesting. So I forgive the flashbacks being drags since it laid the groundwork for some of the best LOST storytelling and themes.

Overall taken as a whole it was a 6/10 show with 7/10 moments. If you remove the socio-culture parts of it relying on word of mouth, conspiracy theories, and audience-driven mystique.. it's like a 5/10 show.
And I'm somebody who liked the ending.

>>180020493
>Overall taken as a whole it was a 6/10 show with 7/10 moments. If you remove the socio-culture parts of it relying on word of mouth, conspiracy theories, and audience-driven mystique.. it's like a 5/10 show.

Lol. This is the worst take I've ever seen. LOST has at least like 5 10/10 moments each season and some of the best individual episodes of television ever made, as well as some of the best characters ever portrayed on network television.

It's also total bullshit that LOST is only good with the water cooler discussion on a week to week basis. Myself and many others discovered the show after it had finished airing and enjoyed it just as much, if not more than the people who watched it when it was airing.

You really think the likes of Through the Looking Glass, The Constant, and Exodus, for example, only rise to the level of a 7/10?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180020493
>it's like a 5/10 show.

I fully acknowledge that LOST is far from perfect, but a 5/10 show?? Really?? It was the most popular show of the mid 2000's and spawned a million copycats (most of which failed) for a reason. A 5/10 show would never have had the impact that it had.

In fact, I personally genuinely consider it to be one of the greatest and most influential shows ever made. It certainly has flaws, and aspects of it haven't aged well in comparison to shows made today, but I think those things are understandable, given just how many episodes they had to make per season (were it made today, the seasons would probably be at least half the length of what they were), and that for the first 2 and a half seasons, the writers didn't know when or if they could work towards an actual ending.
